Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Supporting Efficient Discrete Box Queries for Sequence Analysis on Large Scale Genome Databases

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research project, conducted jointly by the investigators from the Michigan State University (MSU) and the University of Michigan at Dearborn (UM-D), investigates the issues and techniques for storing and searching/querying large scale k-mer data sets (i.e., overlapping k-length subsequences obtained from genome sequences) for sequence analysis in bioinformatics. Efficient k-mer indexing, storage and retrieval are vital to sequence analysis tasks like error correction as sequencing data set sizes increase vastly. Most existing methods for storing and searching k-mers are optimized for exact or range queries. However, this reliance limits the types of sequence analysis that can be done efficiently. Moreover, most existing methods for storing k-mers do not support efficient storage of k-mers at multiple word lengths. For many sequence analysis problems, including error correction, variant detection, and assembly, searches with multiple word lengths enable better sensitivity and specificity. In this project, various techniques for efficiently supporting so-called (discrete) box queries and other related queries (e.g., hybrid queries) on large scale k-mer data sets for sequence analysis are investigated. The approaches to optimizing box queries in solving sequence analysis problems like the error correction are examined. The storage structure and adoption of box queries for supporting searches with multiple word lengths on k-mer data sets are explored. The results from this research will advance the state of knowledge for storage, indexing and retrieval techniques for genome sequence databases. They are expected to significantly impact current practice in bioinformatics by making available new efficient on-disk solutions for sequence analysis. They will also impact a number of other popular application areas including biometrics, image processing, social network, and E-commerce, where processing non-ordered discrete multidimentional data is crucial.

For many sequence analysis problems, searches with multiple word lengths enable better sensitivity and specificity. In this project, various techniques for efficiently supporting so-called (discrete) box queries and other related queries (e.g., hybrid queries) on large scale k-mer data sets for sequence analysis are investigated. In particular, a new index tree, named the BoND-tree, specially designed for a non-ordered discrete data space characterized by k-mer data sets is developed. The unique properties of the space are exploited to develop new node splitting heuristics for the index tree, and theoretical analysis is performed to show the optimality of the proposed heuristics. Besides the BoND-tree, which is based on data partitioning, space-partitioning based index schemes for box quieres in such a space are also developed. To support a more flexible type of query (i.e., hybrid box and range queries), hybrid index schemes integrating strengths of both box query indexes and range query indexes are studied. To facilitate an efficient index construction for large scale k-mer data sets, bulk loading techniques are also developed for the proposed index trees. In addition, the approaches to optimizing box queries in solving sequence analysis problems like the error correction are examined. The storage structure and adoption of box queries for supporting searches with multiple word lengths on k-mer data sets are also explored. The research in the project will result in the discovery of fundamental properties of the data space for sequence data in bioinformatics, the development of a number of novel storage, indexing and retrieval techniques exploiting the properties of such a data space, and the applications of the proposed techniques for solving important problems in sequence analysis. These results will advance the state of knowledge for storage, indexing and retrieval techniques for genome sequence databases. They are expected to significantly impact current practice in bioinformatics by making available new efficient on-disk solutions for sequence analysis. They will also impact a number of other popular application areas including biometrics, image processing, social network, and E-commerce, where processing non-ordered discrete multidimentional data is crucial.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vast increase in the DNA sequencing capacity in recent years has quickly turned biology into a data-intensive science. Areas as diverse as human medicine, microbial ecology, and evolutionary developmental biology are undergoing a rapid transformation as DNA and RNA sequencing becomes quick, easy, and inexpensive. A wide variety of sequence analysis approaches that make use of fixed-length overlapping subsequences, called k-mers, from genome sequences have been developed. k-mers can be viewed as vectors in a multidimensional Non-ordered Discrete Data Space (NDDS). In this collaborative research project, the investigators from the Michigan State University and the University of Michigan - Dearborn investigate the issues and techniques for storing and searching/querying large scale k-mer datasets for genome sequence analysis in bioinformatics.

 

A set of novel index methods for efficiently supporting so-called box queries in an NDDS are developed. Box queries are a new type of queries that can be applied in many genome sequence analysis problems. The first index method, called the BoND-tree, is developed using the data-partitioning based approach where an overflow node is split by partitioning its indexed data. Analytical results on the I/O properties of box queries and the characteristics of the underlying NDDS are exploited to develop novel heuristics and strategies for building an efficient BoND-tree. The second index method, called the BINDS-tree, is developed using the space-partitioning based index approach where an overflow node is split by partitioning its representing space. The empirical study demonstrates that the query performance of the BINDS-tree is generally better than that of the BoND-tree, especially for skewed data, due to the overlap-free property of the space-partitioning based approach. On the other hand, unlike the BoND-tree, the BINDS-tree cannot guarantee the space utilization. Fortunately, the special strategies adopted for the BINDS-tree such as the singleton dimension inheritance make its space utilization comparable to (slightly worse than) that of the BoND-tree. In the project, two other index methods, called the BoND-SD-tree and the BoSP-forest, are also developed based on the special characteristics of their respective types of genome sequence analysis problems. The former utilizes the selected dimensions observed from back-translated protein queries in DNA databases, while the latter is built around the windowing concept of multiple k-mer searches in local sequence alignments. To facilitate the maintenance of an index tree, efficient techniques for bulking loading, deletions and updates are also investigated. The developed index methods and relevant algorithms are used to solve genome sequence analysis problems such as the genome sequencing error correction, the primer design for genome sequence databases, the back-translated protein sequence queries in DNA k-mer databases, the local sequence alignment, and the sequence variant verification/detection. To tackle the challenges for supporting sequence analysis problems to access k-mer datasets at multiple lengths, a novel virtual approximate store approach, called the VA-Store, is suggested. Box queries on the virtual stores are transformed into ones on the physical store. Query optimization and accuracy estimation are studied. In this project, other techniques such as the k-NN search strategies for hybrid data spaces, the topological transformation schemes for efficiently processing range queries, and the performance-guaranteed approximate range query processing method are also explored.

The techniques developed in this research are the first of such kind to tackle their respective challenges. They represent the state-of-art solutions for the relevant indexing, searching, and storing problems for non-ordered discrete data in the database field. They also offer new approaches to solving contemporary genome sequence analysis problems in bioinformatics. Furthermore, they are expected to have an impact on a number of other application areas including biometrics, image processing, social network, and E-commerce, where processing non-ordered discrete multidimensional data is crucial. The project has trained a number of diverse graduate and undergraduate students in the database and bioinformatics fields through research assistantships and course projects. The research results are disseminated via journal publications, conference presentations, and research seminars.
